Walls in Milnor fiber complexes

Alexander¬†R.¬†Miller Fakult√§t f√ºr Mathematik, Universit√§t Wien, Wien, Austria alexander.r.miller@univie.ac.at
Abstract.

For a real reflection group the reflecting hyperplanes cut out on the unit sphere a simplicial complex called the Coxeter complex. Abramenko showed that each reflecting hyperplane meets the Coxeter complex in another Coxeter complex if and only if the Coxeter diagram contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}. The present paper extends Abramenko‚Äôs result to a wider class of complex reflection groups. These groups have a Coxeter-like presentation and a Coxeter-like complex called the Milnor fiber complex. Our first main theorem classifies the groups whose reflecting hyperplanes meet the Milnor fiber complex in another Milnor fiber complex. To understand better the walls that fail to be Milnor fiber complexes we introduce Milnor walls. Our second main theorem generalizes Abramenko‚Äôs result in a second way. It says that each wall of a Milnor fiber complex is a Milnor wall if and only if the diagram contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}.

1. Introduction

For a real reflection group the reflecting hyperplanes cut out on the unit sphere a simplicial complex called the Coxeter complex. Abramenko [1] showed that each reflecting hyperplane meets the Coxeter complex in another Coxeter complex if and only if the Coxeter diagram contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}.

The present paper extends Abramenko‚Äôs result to a wider class of complex reflection groups. These groups have a Coxeter-like presentation and a Coxeter-like complex called the Milnor fiber complex. Our first main theorem (Theorem¬†1) classifies the groups whose reflecting hyperplanes meet the Milnor fiber complex in another Milnor fiber complex.

To understand better the walls that fail to be Milnor fiber complexes we introduce Milnor walls. These are walls with a type-selected set of chambers generating a Milnor fiber complex. Milnor walls in Coxeter complexes are walls that are Coxeter complexes. Our second main theorem (Theorem¬†2) thus generalizes Abramenko‚Äôs result in a second way: it says each wall of a Milnor fiber complex is a Milnor wall if and only if the diagram contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}.

As a benefit of Theorem¬†2 we find that Abramenko‚Äôs result extends to give yet another equivalent condition in a curious classification [5, Theorem 14] with already 11 equivalent conditions coming from invariant theory, cohomology, combinatorics, and some group characters related to adding random numbers.

1.2. Preliminaries

Call a group presentation of the form (1) admissible. Koster¬†[3] classified admissible presentations and found that the groups are precisely the finite direct products of finite irreducible Coxeter groups and Shephard groups. The classification implies no group has two different admissible presentations. Write R={r1,r2,‚Ä¶,rn}ùëÖsubscriptùëü1subscriptùëü2‚Ä¶subscriptùëüùëõ{R=\{r_{1},r_{2},\ldots,r_{n}\}} and call nùëõn the rank of¬†Gùê∫G.

1.2.1.

The classification uses a graphical notation for admissible presentations. The diagram ŒìŒì\Gamma of (1) has for each risubscriptùëüùëñr_{i} a vertex labeled pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}, and for each pair ri,rjsubscriptùëüùëñsubscriptùëüùëór_{i},r_{j} with mi‚Äãj>2subscriptùëöùëñùëó2m_{ij}>2 an edge labeled mi‚Äãjsubscriptùëöùëñùëóm_{ij} that connects risubscriptùëüùëñr_{i} and rjsubscriptùëüùëór_{j}. We agree to suppress the minimal labels (2‚Äôs¬†on vertices and 3‚Äôs on edges). We say ŒìŒì\Gamma is connected if it has exactly one connected component; the diagram with no vertices is not connected. By subdiagram of ŒìŒì\Gamma we mean a diagram gotten from ŒìŒì\Gamma by removing any number of vertices and all their incident edges.

1.2.3.

Gùê∫G has a representation analogous to the canonical one for Coxeter groups. Fix a vector space VùëâV over ùêÇùêÇ\mathbf{C} of dimension nùëõn. Finite Coxeter groups have a canonical representation as a real reflection group that we view as a reflection group by extending the base field. In general the diagram ŒìŒì\Gamma encodes a canonical faithful representation of Gùê∫G as a reflection group G‚äÇGL‚Äã(V)ùê∫GLùëâG\subset{\rm GL}(V) in which each r‚ààRùëüùëÖr\in R is a reflection¬†[3]. With this identification the reflections in Gùê∫G are precisely the non-identity elements that are conjugate to a power of a generator r‚ààRùëüùëÖr\in R. Call Gùê∫G irreducible if the ùêÇ‚ÄãGùêÇùê∫\mathbf{C}G-module VùëâV is irreducible. This happens if and only if ŒìŒì\Gamma is connected. Shephard groups are irreducible; the trivial group is not.

1.3.

Our first theorem extends Abramenko‚Äôs result to Milnor fiber complexes.

Theorem 1.

Each wall of the Milnor fiber complex ŒîŒî\Delta is again a Milnor fiber complex if and only if the diagram of¬†Gùê∫G contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}, G25subscriptùê∫25G_{25}, or¬†G26subscriptùê∫26G_{26}.

We prove Theorem¬†1 in Section¬†2 by first reducing to the case where Gùê∫G is irreducible and then using the classification together with some enumerative and topological results about ŒîŒî\Delta that relate to the invariant theory of Gùê∫G.

1.3.1.

We recover Abramenko‚Äôs result from Theorem¬†1 by Proposition¬†10, which tells us that for Coxeter complexes all walls that are Milnor fiber complexes must be Coxeter complexes.

Corollary (Abramenko).

Each wall of a Coxeter complex is again a Coxeter complex if and only if the diagram contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}.‚àé

1.4.

Our second theorem generalizes Abramenko‚Äôs result in another way. The observation is that walls in Milnor fiber complexes can still hold Milnor fiber complexes of the same dimension in the sense that certain types of chambers in the wall generate a Milnor fiber complex. We make this precise with the definition of Milnor wall in Section¬†3, and then we prove the following theorem which also implies Abramenko‚Äôs result.

Theorem 2.

Each wall of the Milnor fiber complex ŒîŒî\Delta is a Milnor wall if and only if the diagram of¬†Gùê∫G contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}.

Remark 1.

In [5, Theorem 14] we proved that if Gùê∫G is irreducible, then the diagram of Gùê∫G contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4} if and only if the Foulkes characters œï0,œï1,‚Ä¶,œïnsubscriptitalic-œï0subscriptitalic-œï1‚Ä¶subscriptitalic-œïùëõ\phi_{0},\phi_{1},\ldots,\phi_{n} for Gùê∫G depend only on fixed-space dimension in the sense that œïi‚Äã(g)=œïi‚Äã(h)subscriptitalic-œïùëñùëîsubscriptitalic-œïùëñ‚Ñé\phi_{i}(g)=\phi_{i}(h) whenever dimVg=dimVhdimensionsuperscriptùëâùëîdimensionsuperscriptùëâ‚Ñé\dim V^{g}=\dim V^{h}. See [5, Theorem 14] for 9 other equivalent conditions.

2. Milnor fiber complexes

In this section we prove Theorem¬†1 after some preliminaries. ¬ß2.1 defines the Milnor fiber complex. ¬ß2.2 defines walls. ¬ß2.3 develops some topological results. ¬ß2.4 develops some enumerative results. ¬ß2.5 gives a combinatorial description of the Milnor fiber complex for the full monomial groups. Then in ¬ß2.6 we prove Theorem¬†1.

Recall that the connected components ŒìisubscriptŒìùëñ\Gamma_{i} of ŒìŒì\Gamma partition RùëÖR into disjoint sets RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i} so that

Let nisubscriptùëõùëñn_{i} and Œ¥isubscriptùõøùëñ\delta_{i} be the rank and smallest basic degree of Gisubscriptùê∫ùëñG_{i}, so that ni=|Ri|‚â•1subscriptùëõùëñsubscriptùëÖùëñ1{n_{i}=|R_{i}|\geq 1}, n=n1+n2+‚Ä¶+nNùëõsubscriptùëõ1subscriptùëõ2‚Ä¶subscriptùëõùëÅ{n=n_{1}+n_{2}+\ldots+n_{N}}, and Œ¥i‚â•2subscriptùõøùëñ2\delta_{i}\geq 2 with equality if and only if Gisubscriptùê∫ùëñG_{i} is a Coxeter group.

2.1. The Milnor fiber complex

We define the Milnor fiber complex of Gùê∫G to be the complex ŒîŒî\Delta described by the following theorem. The definition is in terms of cosets g‚ÄãGIùëîsubscriptùê∫ùêºgG_{I} of standard parabolic subgroups GI=‚ü®I‚ü©subscriptùê∫ùêºdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùêºG_{I}=\langle I\rangle (I‚äÇRùêºùëÖI\subset R). If Gùê∫G is a Coxeter group, then the definition is the standard abstract one for the Coxeter complex of Gùê∫G and the properties that we list are well known, see [10]. The geometric construction of the Coxeter complex was generalized to include Shephard groups by Orlik [9]. He called this more general complex the Milnor fiber complex. The abstract definition of the Coxeter complex was later shown to hold for the Milnor fiber complex in the Shephard case¬†[6]. For details about the extension of the definition and the properties to the Shephard case see¬†[4]. The general case of the following theorem follows from the Coxeter and Shephard cases.

2.3. Topological results

The following theorem tells us the homotopy type of the subcomplex ŒîgsuperscriptŒîùëî\Delta^{g} for any element g‚ààGùëîùê∫g\in G. In particular, it tells us the homotopy type of any wall ŒîrsuperscriptŒîùëü\Delta^{r}. It is due to Orlik¬†[9] and appears in the proof of his Theorem 4.1 on p.¬†145 where he observes that ŒîgsuperscriptŒîùëî\Delta^{g} is a deformation retract of the intersection of the fixed space VgsuperscriptùëâùëîV^{g} and the Milnor fiber of Gùê∫G, which has an isolated critical point at the origin.

Theorem (Orlik).

If Gùê∫G is irreducible and g‚ààGùëîùê∫g\in G, then the subcomplex ŒîgsuperscriptŒîùëî\Delta^{g} is homotopy equivalent to a bouquet of (d1‚àí1)psuperscriptsubscriptùëë11ùëù(d_{1}-1)^{p} many (p‚àí1)ùëù1(p-1)-spheres, where p=dimVgùëùdimensionsuperscriptùëâùëîp=\dim V^{g}.

If Gùê∫G is reducible, then the homotopy type of a given ŒîgsuperscriptŒîùëî\Delta^{g} is read off from Orlik‚Äôs result and (6). We highlight the case g=1ùëî1g=1. This case is used in the proof of Theorem¬†1 to help determine if a wall ŒîrsuperscriptŒîùëü\Delta^{r} is a Milnor fiber complex Œî‚Äã(W,S)ŒîùëäùëÜ\Delta(W,S) for some possibly reducible¬†WùëäW.

Proposition 8.

Let nisubscriptùëõùëñn_{i} and Œ¥isubscriptùõøùëñ\delta_{i} be the rank and smallest basic degree of the irreducible factor Gisubscriptùê∫ùëñG_{i}, so that n=n1+n2+‚Ä¶+nNùëõsubscriptùëõ1subscriptùëõ2‚Ä¶subscriptùëõùëÅn=n_{1}+n_{2}+\ldots+n_{N}. Proof.

The Milnor fiber complex is the join Œî1‚àóŒî2‚àó‚Ä¶‚àóŒîNsubscriptŒî1subscriptŒî2‚Ä¶subscriptŒîùëÅ\Delta_{1}*\Delta_{2}*\ldots*\Delta_{N} of the complexes ŒîisubscriptŒîùëñ\Delta_{i} of the irreducible factors Gisubscriptùê∫ùëñG_{i}, and Orlik‚Äôs theorem with g=1ùëî1g=1 tells us that ŒîisubscriptŒîùëñ\Delta_{i} is a bouquet of (Œ¥i‚àí1)nisuperscriptsubscriptùõøùëñ1subscriptùëõùëñ(\delta_{i}-1)^{n_{i}} many (ni‚àí1)subscriptùëõùëñ1(n_{i}-1)-spheres. Hence the result. ‚àé

From Proposition¬†8 we get the following characterization of Coxeter complexes as Milnor fiber complexes that are spheres.

Proposition 9.

‚Äã A Milnor fiber complex is a Coxeter complex if and only if it¬†is¬†a¬†sphere.

Proof.

Proposition¬†8 says ŒîŒî\Delta is a bouquet of (Œ¥1‚àí1)n1‚Äã(Œ¥2‚àí1)n2‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äã(Œ¥N‚àí1)nNsuperscriptsubscriptùõø11subscriptùëõ1superscriptsubscriptùõø21subscriptùëõ2‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùõøùëÅ1subscriptùëõùëÅ(\delta_{1}-1)^{n_{1}}(\delta_{2}-1)^{n_{2}}\ldots(\delta_{N}-1)^{n_{N}} many (n‚àí1)ùëõ1(n-1)-spheres. If N=0ùëÅ0N=0, then ŒîŒî\Delta is a single (‚àí1)1(-1)-sphere and Gùê∫G is the trivial Coxeter group ‚ü®‚àÖ‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©\langle\emptyset\rangle. If N>0ùëÅ0N>0, then the inequalities ni‚â•1subscriptùëõùëñ1n_{i}\geq 1 and Œ¥i‚â•2subscriptùõøùëñ2\delta_{i}\geq 2 imply that the number of spheres equals 1 if and only if each Œ¥isubscriptùõøùëñ\delta_{i} equals¬†222. Hence by ¬ß1.2.5(i) the Milnor fiber complex ŒîŒî\Delta is a single sphere if and only if each Gisubscriptùê∫ùëñG_{i} is a Coxeter group, i.e., if and only if Gùê∫G is a Coxeter group. ‚àé

As a corollary of Proposition¬†9 we have the following.

Proposition 10.

A wall of a Coxeter complex is a Milnor fiber complex if and only if it is a Coxeter complex.

Proof.

Consider a wall of a Coxeter complex. If it is a Coxeter complex, then it is a Milnor fiber complex. If it is a Milnor fiber complex, then because it is also a sphere (being the equator of a sphere) Proposition¬†9 tells us that it is a Coxeter complex. ‚àé

Following [5] we make the following remarkable observation.

Theorem 11.

If Gùê∫G is an irreducible Coxeter or Shephard group, then

fn‚àí2‚Äã(Œîr)=d1‚Äãd2‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äãdn‚àí1subscriptùëìùëõ2superscriptŒîùëüsubscriptùëë1subscriptùëë2‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëõ1f_{n-2}(\Delta^{r})=d_{1}d_{2}\ldots d_{n-1} (13)

for any reflection r‚ààGùëüùê∫r\in G, and the following are equivalent:

  1. (i)

    fn‚àí3‚Äã(Œîg)=d1‚Äãd2‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äãdn‚àí2subscriptùëìùëõ3superscriptŒîùëîsubscriptùëë1subscriptùëë2‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëõ2f_{n-3}(\Delta^{g})=d_{1}d_{2}\ldots d_{n-2} for g‚ààGùëîùê∫g\in G such that dimVg=n‚àí2dimensionsuperscriptùëâùëîùëõ2\dim V^{g}=n-2.

  2. (ii)

    fp‚àí1‚Äã(Œîg)=d1‚Äãd2‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äãdpsubscriptùëìùëù1superscriptŒîùëîsubscriptùëë1subscriptùëë2‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëùf_{p-1}(\Delta^{g})=d_{1}d_{2}\ldots d_{p} for g‚ààGùëîùê∫g\in G and p=dimVgùëùdimensionsuperscriptùëâùëîp=\dim V^{g}.

  3. (iii)

    The diagram of Gùê∫G contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}.

Proof.

As stated above, this is a collection of observations from¬†[5] about Orlik‚ÄìSolomon coexponents (see¬†[5, Prop.¬†13(ii), Thm.¬†14(a)(k), Pf. of Thm.¬†14]) as we now explain. For irreducible Coxeter groups, Eq.¬†(13) was observed by Orlik and Solomon [8, p.¬†271]. In general [5, Thm.¬†14(g)(k)] is the equivalence (ii)‚áî‚áî\Leftrightarrow(iii). So it remains to show that (i) fails for F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}, E6subscriptùê∏6E_{6}, E7subscriptùê∏7E_{7}, E8subscriptùê∏8E_{8}, and Dn‚Äã(n‚â•4)subscriptùê∑ùëõùëõ4D_{n}\ (n\geq 4). This is implicit in the proof of [5, Thm.¬†14]. The exceptional cases F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}, E6subscriptùê∏6E_{6}, E7subscriptùê∏7E_{7}, and E8subscriptùê∏8E_{8} follow from (11) together with the tables of [8], and as explained in the proof of [5, Thm.¬†14], (i) fails for Dnsubscriptùê∑ùëõD_{n} since there is a certain fixed pace YùëåY defined by x1=x2=x3subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2subscriptùë•3x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3} such that BY‚Äã(d1‚àí1)<d1‚Äãd2‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äãdn‚àí2subscriptùêµùëåsubscriptùëë11subscriptùëë1subscriptùëë2‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëõ2B_{Y}(d_{1}-1)<d_{1}d_{2}\ldots d_{n-2}. ‚àé

2.6. Proof of Theorem¬†1

It suffices to assume that Gùê∫G is irreducible by Proposition¬†7.

Coxeter diagram with no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}.

In this case, Abramenko tells us that each wall is a Coxeter complex, and hence a Milnor fiber complex.

Coxeter diagram with a subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}.

Since ŒîŒî\Delta is a Coxeter complex, Proposition¬†10 tells us that any wall of ŒîŒî\Delta that is a Milnor fiber complex must be a Coxeter complex. But Abramenko tells us that not all walls of ŒîŒî\Delta are Coxeter complexes. Hence not all walls of ŒîŒî\Delta are Milnor fiber complexes.

Full monomial groups G‚Äã(m,1,n)ùê∫ùëö1ùëõG(m,1,n) (m‚â•2)ùëö2(m\geq 2).

Proposition¬†12 says that any wall of the Milnor fiber complex of G‚Äã(m,1,n)ùê∫ùëö1ùëõG(m,1,n) is isomorphic to the Milnor fiber complex of G‚Äã(m,1,n‚àí1)ùê∫ùëö1ùëõ1{G(m,1,n-1)}.

Groups of rank 1 and 2.

This case is clear.

The remaining exceptional groups: G25,G26,G32subscriptùê∫25subscriptùê∫26subscriptùê∫32G_{25},G_{26},G_{32}.

Here we use Orlik‚Äôs theorem (see ¬ß2.3), Proposition¬†8, and the cell counts of Theorem¬†11.

But Table¬†1 shows that no irreducible rank-3 Coxeter or Shephard group has 518451845184 elements and smallest basic degree d1subscriptùëë1d_{1} equal to 121212.‚àé

3. Milnor walls

Write Œ©¬Ø=‚à™œÉ‚ààŒ©{œÑ‚ààŒî:œÑ‚äÇœÉ}¬ØŒ©subscriptùúéŒ©conditional-setùúèŒîùúèùúé\overline{\Omega}=\cup_{\sigma\in\Omega}\{\tau\in\Delta:\tau\subset\sigma\} for the simplicial complex generated by a family of simplices Œ©‚äÇŒîŒ©Œî\Omega\subset\Delta. Let (Rk)binomialùëÖùëò\binom{R}{k} be the set of all kùëòk-element subsets of RùëÖR, so that

(Rk)={type‚ÄãœÉ:œÉ‚ààŒî,dimœÉ=k‚àí1}.binomialùëÖùëòconditional-settypeùúéformulae-sequenceùúéŒîdimensionùúéùëò1\binom{R}{k}=\{{\rm type}\,\sigma:\sigma\in\Delta,\ \dim\sigma=k-1\}.
Definition 1.

A wall ŒîrsuperscriptŒîùëü\Delta^{r} of ŒîŒî\Delta is a Milnor wall if for some ‚Ñ±‚äÇ(Rn‚àí1)‚Ñ±binomialùëÖùëõ1\mathcal{F}\subset\binom{R}{n-1} the subcomplex

(Œîr)‚Ñ±={œÉ‚ààŒîr:type‚ÄãœÉ‚àà‚Ñ±}¬ØsubscriptsuperscriptŒîùëü‚Ñ±¬Øconditional-setùúésuperscriptŒîùëütypeùúé‚Ñ±(\Delta^{r})_{\mathcal{F}}=\overline{\{\sigma\in\Delta^{r}:{\rm type}\,\sigma\in\mathcal{F}\}} (15)

is a Milnor fiber complex of dimension n‚àí2ùëõ2n-2. A proper Milnor wall is a Milnor wall that is not a Milnor fiber complex.

Any wall ŒîrsuperscriptŒîùëü\Delta^{r} can be written as (Œîr)‚Ñ±subscriptsuperscriptŒîùëü‚Ñ±(\Delta^{r})_{\mathcal{F}} for ‚Ñ±=(Rn‚àí1)‚Ñ±binomialùëÖùëõ1\mathcal{F}=\binom{R}{n-1}. Therefore walls that are Milnor fiber complexes are Milnor walls. These are the non-proper Milnor walls. They are the only kind of Milnor wall found in Coxeter complexes. This is the following lemma.

Lemma 13.

Coxeter complexes have no proper Milnor walls.

Proof.

A wall in an (n‚àí1)ùëõ1(n-1)-dimensional Coxeter complexes is an (n‚àí2)ùëõ2(n-2)-sphere, and an (n‚àí2)ùëõ2(n-2)-dimensional Milnor fiber complex is a bouquet of (n‚àí2)ùëõ2(n-2)-spheres. Therefore, removing any chambers from a wall of an (n‚àí1)ùëõ1(n-1)-dimensional Coxeter complex gives something that is not a Milnor fiber complex of dimension n‚àí2ùëõ2n-2. ‚àé

Proposition 14.

A wall of a Coxeter complex is a Milnor wall if and only if the wall is a Coxeter complex.

Proof.

Suppose Œ£Œ£\Sigma is a Milnor wall of a Coxeter complex. Then Lemma¬†13 implies that Œ£Œ£\Sigma is a Milnor fiber complex. Since Œ£Œ£\Sigma is a wall of a Coxeter complex, it follows from Proposition¬†10 that Œ£Œ£\Sigma is a Coxeter complex. The other direction is clear: a wall of a Coxeter complex that is itself a Coxeter complex is a (non-proper) Milnor wall. ‚àé

Proposition 15.

Each wall of Œî‚Äã(G,R)Œîùê∫ùëÖ\Delta(G,R) is a Milnor wall if and only if each wall of each Œî‚Äã(Gi,Ri)Œîsubscriptùê∫ùëñsubscriptùëÖùëñ\Delta(G_{i},R_{i}) is a Milnor wall.

3.1. Proof of Theorem¬†2

It suffices to assume that Gùê∫G is irreducible by Proposition¬†15.

Suppose that the diagram of Gùê∫G contains no subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}, and that Gùê∫G is not G25subscriptùê∫25G_{25}, G26subscriptùê∫26G_{26}, or G32subscriptùê∫32G_{32}. Then Theorem¬†1 tells us that each wall of ŒîŒî\Delta is a Milnor fiber complex. Hence each wall of ŒîŒî\Delta is a Milnor wall.

Suppose now the diagram of Gùê∫G contains a subdiagram of type D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, F4subscriptùêπ4F_{4}, or H4subscriptùêª4H_{4}. By the irreducibility of Gùê∫G and the classification (Table¬†1), Gùê∫G must be a Coxeter group. Then Abremenko‚Äôs result tells us that not all walls of ŒîŒî\Delta are Coxeter complexes, and Proposition¬†14 tells us that the Milnor walls of ŒîŒî\Delta are the walls of ŒîŒî\Delta that are again Coxeter complexes. So in this case we conclude that not all walls of ŒîŒî\Delta are Milnor walls.

Finally suppose Gùê∫G is G25subscriptùê∫25G_{25}, G26subscriptùê∫26G_{26}, or G32subscriptùê∫32G_{32}. The object is to show that all walls are Milnor walls. The remainder of the proof explains how this claim follows from Orlik‚Äôs original construction of the Milnor fiber complex ŒîŒî\Delta together with some observations made by Coxeter about the regular complex polytopes associated to G25subscriptùê∫25G_{25}, G26subscriptùê∫26G_{26}, and G32subscriptùê∫32G_{32}.

A regular complex polytope¬†[2, p.¬†115] is a certain collection ùí´ùí´\mathscr{P} of affine subspaces in ùêÇnsuperscriptùêÇùëõ\mathbf{C}^{n} with incidence relation given by proper inclusion subject to some conditions. The symmetry group of a regular complex polytope is a Shephard group Gùê∫G and the Milnor fiber complex of the Shephard group is constructed in [9] as a geometric realization of the flag complex of the poset of simplices of ùí´ùí´\mathscr{P}, whose kùëòk-simplices are the flags ‚Ñ±=(F(0)‚ääF(1)‚ää‚Ä¶‚ääF(k))‚Ñ±superscriptùêπ0superscriptùêπ1‚Ä¶superscriptùêπùëò{\mathscr{F}}=(F^{(0)}\subsetneq F^{(1)}\subsetneq\ldots\subsetneq F^{(k)}) of faces F(i)‚ààùí´superscriptùêπùëñùí´{F^{(i)}\in\mathscr{P}}; see [9, Thm.¬†5.1]. Index the generators of the Shephard group starting with 00 instead of 111, so that R={r0,r1,‚Ä¶,rn‚àí1}ùëÖsubscriptùëü0subscriptùëü1‚Ä¶subscriptùëüùëõ1{R=\{r_{0},r_{1},\ldots,r_{n-1}\}}. Then a flag ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±\mathscr{F} corresponds in the Milnor fiber complex to a coset of ‚ü®R‚àñ{rdimF:F‚àà‚Ñ±}‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëÖconditional-setsubscriptùëüdimensionùêπùêπ‚Ñ±\langle R\setminus\{r_{\dim F}:F\in\mathscr{F}\}\rangle, whose type is {rdimF:F‚àà‚Ñ±}conditional-setsubscriptùëüdimensionùêπùêπ‚Ñ±\{r_{\dim F}:F\in\mathscr{F}\}; see [4].

Coxeter considered the section of ùí´ùí´\mathscr{P} by a reflecting hyperplane HùêªH. This is the set

{F‚ààùí´:F‚äÇF‚Ä≤‚äÇH‚Äãfor some¬†‚ÄãF‚Ä≤‚ààùí´‚Äãsuch that¬†‚ÄãdimF‚Ä≤=n‚àí2}.conditional-setùêπùí´ùêπsuperscriptùêπ‚Ä≤ùêªfor some¬†superscriptùêπ‚Ä≤ùí´such that¬†dimensionsuperscriptùêπ‚Ä≤ùëõ2\{F\in\mathscr{P}:F\subset F^{\prime}\subset H\ \text{for some }F^{\prime}\in\mathscr{P}\ \text{such that }\dim F^{\prime}=n-2\}. (17)

He observed the following¬†[2, pp. 123, 132]: if G=G25ùê∫subscriptùê∫25G=G_{25}, then each section of ùí´ùí´\mathscr{P} by a reflecting hyperplane is a regular complex polytope for G‚Äã(3,1,2)ùê∫312G(3,1,2); if G=G26ùê∫subscriptùê∫26G=G_{26}, then each section of ùí´ùí´\mathscr{P} by a reflecting hyperplane is a regular complex polytope for either G‚Äã(3,1,2)ùê∫312G(3,1,2) or G‚Äã(6,1,2)ùê∫612G(6,1,2); and if G=G32ùê∫subscriptùê∫32G=G_{32}, then each section of ùí´ùí´\mathscr{P} by a reflecting hyperplane is a regular complex polytope for G26subscriptùê∫26G_{26}. These observations translate into the following statements about Œ£=(Œî‚Äã(G,R)r)‚Ñ±Œ£subscriptŒîsuperscriptùê∫ùëÖùëü‚Ñ±\Sigma=(\Delta(G,R)^{r})_{\mathcal{F}} for ‚Ñ±={R‚àñ{rn‚àí1}}‚Ñ±ùëÖsubscriptùëüùëõ1\mathcal{F}=\{R\setminus\{r_{n-1}\}\} and r‚ààGùëüùê∫r\in G a reflection.

  1. a.

    If G=G25ùê∫subscriptùê∫25G=G_{25}, then Œ£Œ£\Sigma is isomorphic to the Milnor fiber complex of G‚Äã(3,1,2)ùê∫312G(3,1,2).

  2. b.

    If G=G26ùê∫subscriptùê∫26G=G_{26}, then Œ£Œ£\Sigma is isomorphic to the Milnor fiber complex of G‚Äã(3,1,2)ùê∫312G(3,1,2) or G‚Äã(6,1,2)ùê∫612G(6,1,2).

  3. c.

    If G=G32ùê∫subscriptùê∫32G=G_{32}, then Œ£Œ£\Sigma is isomorphic to the Milnor fiber complex of G26subscriptùê∫26G_{26}.

Hence if Gùê∫G is G25subscriptùê∫25G_{25}, G26subscriptùê∫26G_{26}, or G32subscriptùê∫32G_{32}, then all walls of Œî‚Äã(G,R)Œîùê∫ùëÖ\Delta(G,R) are Milnor walls. ‚àé
